importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication, indicating the current stage of the postseason and the Mariners' historic proximity to their first World Series appearance.
The year when the Mariners defeated the Yankees in the ALDS, which many believe saved baseball in Seattle, establishing a foundational moment in franchise history.
The year of the 2001 ALCS, where Bret Boone's homer marked a significant moment in Mariners postseason history, and the last time the team had a game-tying homer in the eighth or later.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeframe during which the Mariners are in a decisive position in the postseason, just one win away from their first World Series appearance.
The period leading up to Suárez’s grand slam, during which the Mariners were facing a critical series situation and needed a decisive hit to gain momentum.

keyTakeAways: Eugenio Suárez hit a grand slam in the bottom of the eighth inning, giving the Seattle Mariners a 6-2 lead over the Toronto Blue Jays and moving them within one win of their first World Series appearance.
This is the second grand slam in Mariners postseason history, highlighting a rare and historic moment in franchise baseball history.
The Mariners are now leading the series 3-2, with Game 6 scheduled for Sunday night in Toronto.
Seattle has never made it to the World Series, making this moment a pivotal point in franchise history and a source of emotional significance for fans.
Cal Raleigh hit a game-tying home run in the eighth inning, the first such homer in that inning since 2001, signaling a resurgence in team momentum.
Suárez’s performance was emotional, with him bringing his daughters to the postgame press conference, underscoring personal and familial significance.
The Mariners’ 1995 ALDS victory is remembered as a turning point that saved baseball in Seattle, adding historical context to the current moment.
Raleigh now has 64 home runs in the season, tied with Aaron Judge for the most in a single year in the American League.

namedEntities.name: Eugenio Suárez
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Suárez’s grand slam in the eighth inning was the decisive moment that propelled the Mariners to within one win of their first World Series appearance, marking a historic and emotional peak in franchise history.

namedEntities.name: Seattle Mariners
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Mariners are the subject of the article, and their historic near-miss in the postseason underscores their long-standing absence from the World Series, making this moment a turning point in franchise history.

namedEntities.name: Toronto Blue Jays
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Blue Jays are the opposing team in the playoff series, and their earlier wins in Seattle created a pivotal series situation that Suárez’s performance ultimately overcame.

namedEntities.name: Dan Wilson
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: As the team’s manager, Dan Wilson provided commentary on the emotional impact of Suárez’s hit and the historic noise of the crowd, adding context to the significance of the moment.

namedEntities.name: Cal Raleigh
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Raleigh’s game-tying homer in the eighth inning was a pivotal moment that revived team momentum and tied the game before Suárez’s grand slam, making it a key part of the narrative.

namedEntities.name: Bryce Miller
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Miller’s early exit in the fifth inning allowed the Blue Jays to score, highlighting a key turning point in the game and the team’s vulnerability.

namedEntities.name: George Springer
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Springer’s two-out double in the fifth inning brought home a run, contributing to the team’s ability to stay in the game despite early setbacks.

namedEntities.name: Ernie Clement
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Clement drove in a run with a single in the sixth inning, helping to extend the Mariners’ lead and contribute to the team’s momentum.

namedEntities.name: Addison Barger
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Barger was driven in by George Springer’s double, marking a key scoring play in the fifth inning.

namedEntities.name: Alejando Kirk
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Kirk was driven in by Ernie Clement’s single, adding another run to the Mariners’ lead in the sixth inning.

namedEntities.name: Bret Boone
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Boone’s homer in Game 4 of the 2001 ALCS is referenced as the last time a game-tying homer was hit in the eighth or later, making Raleigh’s homer a historic milestone.

namedEntities.name: Aaron Judge
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Judge is mentioned as being tied with Cal Raleigh in total home runs for a single season, highlighting the significance of Raleigh’s achievement.

namedEntities.name: New York Yankees
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Yankees are referenced as the team that the Mariners narrowly lost to in the 1995 ALDS and in a previous playoff run, establishing historical context for the franchise’s postseason struggles.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Eugenio Suárez hit a grand slam in the bottom of the eighth inning, giving the Seattle Mariners a 6-2 lead over the Toronto Blue Jays and moving them just one win away from their first-ever World Series appearance. This marks the second grand slam in franchise postseason history and a pivotal moment in a long-standing history of near-misses. The Mariners, who have never made it to the Fall Classic, are now leading the series 3-2, with Game 6 set for Sunday in Toronto. The emotional impact of Suárez’s hit, amplified by the presence of his daughters and the historic crowd noise, underscores the significance of the moment. Cal Raleigh’s game-tying homer in the eighth inning — the first in that inning since 2001 — also played a key role in the momentum shift. The article draws on historical context, including the 1995 ALDS win over the Yankees and the 2001 ALCS, to highlight how this moment could finally break the franchise’s long drought in reaching the World Series.
title: Eugenio Suárez grand slam powers Seattle Mariners to within one win of first World Series
